Effect of chlorine on the performance of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for n-hexane dehydrogenation Xiuyi Li Investigation Data curation Validation Writing – original draft Jianxiang Li Investigation Validation Mengzhen Yuan Validation Ning Li Investigation Validation Jiale Xu Guowei Wang Conceptualization Validation ⁎ Chunyi Li Conceptualization Validation Resources Writing – review & editing ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, East China, Qingdao 266555, PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum, East China Qingdao 266555 PR China State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing, China University of Petroleum (East China), Qingdao 266555, P.R. China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. Dehydrogenation of n-hexane on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can produce n-hexenes and benzene efficiently, while the catalyst deactivates rapidly. This work discovers that introducing an appropriate amount of Cl (NH4Cl) to the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can significantly improve catalytic activity and enhance stability, which is caused by increased proportion of Cr6+ oxides and number of Lewis acid sites, improved dispersion of CrOx and depressed coke deposition. While excessive Cl further increases the acidity of the catalyst, accelerating the side reactions like cracking and isomerization, meanwhile the inactive Cr-Cl species are formed inevitably. Surprisingly, introducing Cl in the form of KCl can effectively avoid these negative influences owing to the strong interaction between Cl and K. For 13 wt%Cr-2.5 wt%KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, 61.2 wt% of n-hexane conversion, 93.1 wt% of selectivity to dehydrogenation products can be achieved, in which the selectivities to n-hexene and benzene are 20.4 wt% and 70.1 wt%, respectively. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords n-Hexane Dehydrogenation Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Chlorine n-Hexene Benzene Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction CrOx-based catalysts are widely used for alkane dehydrogenation reaction due to their excellent C-H activation ability and olefin selectivity, like the Catofin process for propane and isobutane dehydrogenation to mono-olefin, and the Catodiene process for pentene dehydrogenation to di-olefin [1,2]. The dehydrogenation performance of CrOx catalyst is closely related to the state of surface Cr species. It is generally recognized that Cr3+ corresponds to the catalytic activity of dehydrogenation reaction, but the dehydrogenation performance varies according to the state of Cr3+ species [3–6]. While some other researchers proposed that the dehydrogenation activity depends on the number of Cr species with the high oxidation state (Cr6+ and Cr5+) [4], or the views that Cr2+ are the active species for dehydrogenation reaction [7]. Introducing alkali or alkaline-earth metal into CrOx/Al2O3 could neutralize the acidic center of Al2O3 support that catalyze the side reactions such as cracking. Moreover, an appropriate amount alkali metal also changes the distribution and reducibility of Cr species by forming chromate or dichromate, thus modifying the dehydrogenation performance [8]. n-Hexane usually presents in naphtha and reformate, and it is hard to turn into the desired products in both steam cracking and reforming process [9]. Dehydrogenation of n-hexane realizes the effective utilization of n-hexane to produce high value-added products, which are widely used in the synthesis of polymerized monomer, lubricating base oil and other chemical intermediate. For the n-hexane dehydrogenation reaction, there are a large number of deep dehydrogenation products benzene formed except for n-hexene [10]. Some researchers presumed that n-hexane dehydrogenating to benzene through continuous dehydrogenation reaction, that is n-hexane → n-hexene → … → benzene [11]. Timofeeva et al. [12] obtained 36 % n-hexane conversion at 500 oC when using Cr2O3-K2O/Al2O3 for n-hexane dehydrogenation, and the yields of n-hexene and benzene were 12 % and 22 %, respectively. They proposed that benzene comes from the deep dehydrogenation of n-hexene, while the catalyst deactivates rapidly owing to the serious coking. Generally, it is regarded that the aromatization of alkanes requires acid sites, like catalytic reforming of naphtha and aromatization of C4 [13]. Liu et al. [14] reported the n-hexane dehydro-aromatization behavior of Pt-Zn/S-1 (Silicalite-1), which showed excellent propane dehydrogenation performance. The conversion of n-hexane was 75.6 % at 550 oC and the selectivity to benzene was 76.8 %. They suggested that the n-hexane aromatized to benzene over Pt-Zn/S-1 catalyst follows a metal-acid bifunctional mechanism. Thus far, the effect of acidity on the formation of benzene in n-hexane dehydrogenation is still unclear, and the problems for the fast deactivation of CrOx catalyst is unsolved. Chlorine is usually used to modify the acid properties of the catalyst, and the typical examples are the Pt-Sn/Al2O3-Cl catalyst in catalytic reforming process and the Pt/Al2O3-Cl catalyst for isomerization reaction, both of which get more acid centers from Cl [15]. Besides, sometimes Cl is considered to have a promotional effect due to the electron-deficient property, by modifying the chemisorption capacity, microstructure, and dispersion of supported species [16–18]. While sometimes Cl possesses toxic effect on the catalytic performance due to the formation of inacitve metal-Cl or metal-O-Cl species [19], like Pt, Ru, Rh, etc [20]. Ali et al. [21] found that doping Cl to Pt/Al2O3 increased the acidity of the catalyst, promoting the acid dominated reactions like isomerization and aromatization, while a large amount of Cl facilitated the formation of inactive Pt-Cl species. In this work, Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with 13 wt% Cr and 2.5 wt% K was prepared, and different sources and contents of Cl were introduced to investigate the effect of Cl on the catalyst, including the acid property, the microstructure, the state of the surface Cr species, and the n-hexane dehydrogenation performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation All of the catalysts were prepared by initial wet impregnation technique. A series of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 with different Cl levels were prepared as follows: a solution containing amounts of Cr(NO3)3·9 H2O (AR.), KNO3 (AR.) and NH4Cl (AR.) was added to γ-Al2O3 power, then dried 12 h in a rotary evaporator at 95 oC, finally calcined under 600 oC at muffle for 4 h with the heating rate of 2 oC/min. The obtained catalysts were labeled as Cr-K-xCl/γ-Al2O3, where the suffix x indicates the nominal loading of Cl, and ranges in 0–10. The Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different K contents were prepared by the same method, using Cr(NO3)3·9 H2O and KCl (AR.) as Cr, K and Cl precursors, γ-Al2O3 as support. The samples were calcined under 600 oC at muffle for 4 h (10 oC/min), and designated as Cr-xKCl/γ-Al2O3, where the suffix x represents the nominal content of K. The CrCl3/x-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared identical with the formers, using CrCl3·6 H2O (AR.) as precursor, γ-Al2O3 or θ-Al2O3 as support. The obtained samples were calcined in tubular furance under N2 atmosphere at 600 oC for 4 h or 8 h, or 0.05 MPa N2 environment at 750 oC for 4 h or 8 h, and labeled as CrCl3/x-Al2O3-a-b-c, where the x, a, b and c represent the crystalline phase of alumina, calcination pressure, temperature and time, respectively. The γ-Al2O3 and θ-Al2O3 support were obtained by gelation pseudoboehmite powder (AR. 67 wt%) with fuming HNO3, and calcined at 650 oC or 950 oC (10 °C/min) for 6 h, finally milled and screened to 250–450 µm (40–60 mesh) particles. The XRD patterns of γ-Al2O3 and θ-Al2O3 supports are displayed in Fig. S1. 2.2 Catalytic activity test n-Hexane dehydrogenation reactions were conducted in a quartz down-flow fixed-bed microreactor (12 mm i.d.) at 500 oC under atmospheric pressure. About 1.0 g catalyst was loaded in the middle of reactor and heated from room temperature to 500 oC with flowing N2 (99.999 %) and kept 30 min to remove the impurities. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was pretreated in situ with 30 mL/min H2 (99.99 %) for 60 min. During the test, n-hexane (99.4 % purity) was fed to the reactor with 20 mL/min N2 as diluent gas. The WHSV of n-hexane was 2.5 h-1. The catalytic activity was measured for 4 h. The composition of feed and product was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (PANNA GCA60) with an FID detector and a PONA column (50 m × 0.2 mm). The outlet products were kept 140 oC by the heater belt and delivered to the gas chromatograph. The conversion of n-hexane and the selectivity to product was calculated as follows: Selectivity to product i ( wt % ) = i out − i in n − hexane in − n − hexane out × 100 % Supposing the catalyst deactivated in dehydrogenation reaction follows the first-order mechanism, and describing catalyst stability by the relative deactivation rate (R): R ( h − 1 ) = ln 1 − X end X end − ln 1 − X start X start t Where the Xend and Xstart represents the n-hexane conversion at the end and the start of the reaction, and t is the duration of the reaction in hours. The higher the R values the rapid the catalyst deactivation, that is, low stability. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The surface area and pore structure of the catalyst were measured by the BET and BJH method using Quadrasorb SI multifunctional adsorption equipment. The actual Cl content of catalyst was determined by X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (ARL9800 XRF), operated at 50 kV and 50 mA. The crystal structure was tested by an X-ray diffractometer (X'Pert PRO MPD), operated at 40 kV and 40 mA, using Cu Ka radiation with a scanning speed of 10 o/min. TEM image was obtained on a JEOL 2010 with a LaB6 filament as electron source operating with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. 1-Hexene-TPD was tested in a fixed-bed microreactor connected to an online GAS-100Q quadrupole mass spectrometer. About 100 mg catalysts were reduced under H2 (5 % H2/Ar, 30 mL/min) at 500 °C for 1 h. Afterward, a flow of Ar (99.99 %, 30 mL/min) was introduced until the temperature was cooled to 20 °C. The adsorption of 1-hexene was performed by a stream of 1-hexene vapor at 20 °C for 30 min, where the 1-hexene was diluted with Ar (the molar ratio of Ar to 1-hexene was about 4). The catalyst bed was blowed out by Ar (30 mL/min) for 2 h to remove physisorbed 1-hexene. Then the temperature was rose to 500 oC (5 oC/min), and MS signal was recorded at the same time, of which m/z = 41, 2 and 16 represent 1-hexene, H2 and CH4, respectively. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out in a PCA-1200 chemisorption analyzer (BJbuilder, China). About 100 mg (250–450 µm) samples were heated under He (99.99 %, 30 mL/min) at 600 oC for 1 h, then cooled down to 100 oC and reduced in a flow of mixture gas (5 % H2/Ar, 30 mL/min), raising the temperature from 100 oC to 800 oC with the heating rate of 10 oC/min. Temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed in a PCA-1200 chemisorption analyzer. About 100 mg (250–450 µm) samples were heated under He (30 mL/min) at 600 oC for 1 h, then cooled down and stabilize at 100 oC, followed by adsorbing NH3 (20 % NH3/N2) for 30 min. Finally, the temperature rose from 100 °C to 650 °C with a rate of 10 °C/min under He (30 mL/min). Pyridine fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR) experiment was conducted to describe the acid type of catalyst, which using a Tensor 27 FTIR spectrometer. The spectra were recorded with the resolution of 4 cm-1 and 64 scans. The coke content of used catalyst was measured by 1HW(T) HF infrared sulfur/carbon analyzer, by quantifying the content of the CO2 after calcinating the spent catalyst in O2 (99.99 %). Decomposition behavior of CrCl30·6 H2O and KCl was measured by TGA or MS-TGA analysis (TGA, PerkinElmer TGA Pyris 1). The samples were heating from room temperature to 800 °C in a flow of N2 or air (30 mL/min) at a ramping rate 10 °C/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of Cl on the n-hexane dehydrogenation performance: NH4Cl as precursor 3.1.1 Microstructure of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl contents The textural properties and the actual Cl content of Cr-K-xCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are listed in Table 1. As shown, introducing Cl has less impact on the BET surface area and pore volume of the samples, and the difference between the actual and nominal loading of Cl element is little. These facts indicate that the introduced Cl species is retained in the catalyst after calcination. The XRD patterns of Cr-K-xCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1. All the samples show diffraction peaks corresponding to crystalline Cr2O3 at 2θ of 24.5, 33.6, 36.3, 50.2 and 55.0 o [7,22]. While these peaks become weaker and broader (see the FWHM data listed in Table S2) as the Cl content increases to 1.5 wt%, indicating that the dispersion of Cr2O3 gets better on the surface. With the weakening of the diffraction peaks of Cr2O3, new peaks at 2θ of 28.3, 31.7 and 40.6 o are assigned to KCl and CrCl3 appear for the Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [23–25]. This further suggests that Cl is indeed loaded on the catalyst, which is consistent with the BET and element analysis results. 3.1.2 n-Hexane dehydrogenation behaviors of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl contents Fig. 2a shows the evolution of n-hexane conversion for Cr-K-xCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts measured in 4 h. For the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the initial conversion of n-hexane is 46.5 wt%, and it decreases rapidly with time on stream (TOS), finally reduces to 29.5 wt% at 4 h. After introducing a small amount of Cl, the conversion of n-hexane is improved, reaching the highest value of 52.2 wt% over Cr-K-1.0Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at the initial stage of the reaction, which is quite stable during the 4 h reaction. The Cr-K-0.5Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits a similar n-hexane conversion trend. When the Cl content increases to 1.5 wt%, the initial conversion declines to 46.2 wt%, and as the Cl content increases further to 10 wt%, the n-hexane conversion is only 0.7 wt%, i.e. the catalyst become almost inactive. The initial n-hexane conversion of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl loadings decreases in the order of Cr-K-1.0Cl/γ-Al2O3 ≈ Cr-K-0.5Cl/γ-Al2O3 > Cr-K-1.5Cl/γ-Al2O3 > Cr-K-0.2Cl/γ-Al2O3 > Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 > > Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3. Compared with Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the descendant trend of the n-hexane conversion for Cl-modified catalyst obviously slows down. In order to describe the stability of the catalyst, the coke content and relative deactivation rate (R) of used catalyst were calculated, which are shown in Fig. 2b. The R values of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is 1.52 h-1, and it decreases to 0.01–0.02 h-1 as the Cl loadings vary in the range of 0.2–1.5 wt%. The lowest relative deactivation rate is obtained on Cr-K-0.5Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The amount of coke on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst after 4 h reaction is 4.7 wt%, while it drops significantly after introducing Cl. The coke content of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with 0.2 wt% − 1.5 wt% Cl are similar, at about 2.0 wt%. The relative deactivation rate and the coke content of inactive Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are not discussed. The selectivity to different products (a) and the proportion of three dehydrogenation products (b) for n-hexane dehydrogenation over Cr-K-xCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts at TOS of 1 h are depicted in Fig. 3. The products of n-hexane dehydrogenation are classified as dehydrogenation products (including n-hexene, n-hexdiene and benzene), isomerization products (hydrocarbons with six carbon atoms except for n-hexane, n-hexene, n-hexdiene and benzene) and cracking products (the sum of C1-C5 hydrocarbons). There is no COx in the products. For the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the selectivities to dehydrogenation products, cracking products and isomerization products are 93.7 wt%, 2.3 wt% and 0.1 wt%, respectively. While the selectivity to dehydrogenation products decreases slightly as the Cl loading increasing within 1.5 wt%. On the contrary, the selectivity to cracking and isomerization products follows the opposite trend, it rises slowly with Cl loading. For Cr-K-1.5Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the selectivities to dehydrogenation products, cracking products and isomerization products are 87.2 wt%, 5.4 wt% and 6.2 wt%, respectively. Increasing Cl loading to 10 wt%, the selectivity to dehydrogenation products drops to 10.6 wt%, while the selectivities to cracking and isomerization products rise to 28.5 wt% and 34.4 wt%. Besides, it can be observed that the ratio of n-hexene, n-hexdiene and benzene to total dehydrogenation products are kept constant as the Cl content varies within 1.5 wt%, and fluctuate slightly when the Cl loading increases to 10 wt%. The results of blank experiment and over pure Al2O3 are listed in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. 3.1.3 Acid property of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl contents Py-FTIR and NH3-TPD analysis were carried out to clarify the impact of the Cl on the acid properties of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3. The Py-FTIR spectra of the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl contents are displayed in Fig. 4. As seen, compared with Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, Cl modified catalysts exhibit more prominent IR absorption bands located at 1450, 1490, 1540, 1575, 1595 and 1615 cm-1, and the intensity of these bands is enhanced as increasing Cl content, especially for the bands at 1450 and 1490 cm-1. Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst also shows IR absorption bands at 1623 cm-1. In general, the IR absorption bands at about 1450 cm-1 and 1540 cm-1 represent the pyridinium ions chemisorbed on Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, respectively, and the band at about 1490 cm-1 is assigned to the pyridinium ions chemisorbed on both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [26,27]. According to the studies of Liu and Yue [27,28], the IR absorption bands at 1575, 1595 and 1615 cm-1 are attributed to the medium strong Lewis acid sites, while the absorption band at 1623 cm-1 is related to the pyridine ions interact with strong Lewis acid sites. All of these indicate that both numbers of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites increases with Cl loading, while the effect of Cl on the Lewis acid sites is greater than the Brønsted acid sites, since the intensities of IR absorption bands at 1450 cm-1 and 1490 cm-1 shows larger growth trend than that at 1540 cm-1 with the increase of Cl content, and strong Lewis acid site appears as the Cl loading increases to 10 wt%. The NH3-TPD profiles and the acid amounts determined by integrating the NH3 desorption curves of Cr-K-xCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5. As observed, the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst presents two inseparable NH3 desorption peaks in the temperature range from 150 °C to 380 °C, which are characterized to the desorbed NH3 from the weak (I) and medium strong (II) acid sites [26]. The NH3-TPD curves of Cl modified catalysts with Cl loading lower than 1.5 wt% are similar with that of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3. The Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst shows three inseparable desorption peaks in the temperature range of 160–510 °C, which are attributed to the weak (I), medium strong (II) and strong acid centers (III) [29]. Excessive Cl probably brings strong acid centers, and increases the desorption temperature of NH3 [30,31]. This is consistent with the Py-IR results. The total number of acid sites for Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is only 3.27 umol/g due to the presence of potassium that neutralizes the acid centers [8]. The amount of acid sites is increased after introducing Cl, and rises gradually with Cl loading, and reaching the maximum of 6.93 umol/g for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. 3.1.4 State of Cr species on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl contents Fig. 6 illustrates the H2 reduction curves of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl contents. As shown, except for the Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3, all samples exhibit a prominent peak at around 360 oC, which is usually assigned to the reduction of the isolated single or polymeric Cr6+ oxides [4]. Moreover, the small shoulder peaks at about 440 oC and 550 oC are attributed to Cr6+ oxides that strongly interacted with alumina support or potassium, which are more difficult to be reduced than the isolated Cr6+ oxides [8,32]. The isolated Cr6+ oxides are predominant among the Cr6+ oxides when the Cl content lower than 1.5 wt%. While for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3, almost no TCD signal during the H2-TPR process is observed, suggesting that no chromium oxide could be reduced. The peak temperature of reduction for isolated Cr6+ oxides in the H2-TPR profiles (are listed in Table 2) is increases after adding Cl and rises with Cl content. In addition, the proportion of Cr6+ oxides to total Cr species in catalyst was calculated by integrating the H2-TPR peaks according to the reducibility of CrOx [22,33], and the results are listed in Table 2. The proportion of Cr6+ to total Cr in Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is 9.08 %, and it is increases to 12.24 % with the Cl content rising to 1.0 wt%, then drops to 9.32 % as the Cl content ascending to 1.5 wt%. The reduction behavior of Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is irregular, and the proportion of Cr6+ oxides can not be determined. Thus, the introduced chlorine changes the proportion of Cr6+ oxides and make it more difficult to be reduced. Fig. 7 shows the TEM images of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3, Cr-K-1.0Cl/γ-Al2O3 and Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. As observed, except for the small clusters of CrOx, there are several huge CrOx particles larger than 100 nm for Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and the largest particle size is 180.4 nm. The CrOx grains get more uniform on Al2O3 support after adding Cl, consistent with XRD results. CrOx appears in granular clusters, and no large CrOx particles greater than 30 nm can be detected for Cr-K-1.0Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The CrOx distributes so homogeneously on the alumina support for the Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst that the CrOx can not be distinguished in the “cottony” like mixture of CrOx and Al2O3. This further confirms that the introduction of Cl changes the state of Cr species on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Generally, it is difficult to define the size of metal oxide particles when using oxide as the support unless the metal oxide particles are large enough. Thus the distribution of CrOx particles size can not be identified directly through TEM analysis. Both H2-TPR and TEM results suggest that the introduction of Cl affects the state of Cr species on the surface, thus enhancing the activity and stability of the catalyst. 3.1.5 Structure-activity relationship of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with different Cl contents The n-hexane conversion and stability of the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are significantly improved with the introduction of 0.2–1.5 wt% Cl, the coking reaction is also depressed at the same time. H2-TPR experiments indicate that the distribution of various CrOx in the catalyst is changed after introducing Cl. With the increases of Cl loading, the ratio of Cr6+ oxides to total CrOx in catalyst is firstly incresaed, and then decreased. As depicted in Fig. 8, there is a linear relationship between n-hexane conversion and the proportion of Cr6+ oxides in catalyst, that is, the more the Cr6+ oxides, the higher n-hexane conversion can be obtained. The total number of active Cr3+ on the catalyst surface is increased with Cr6+ oxides [34,35], thus promoting the conversion of n-hexane. Moreover, Lewis acid is generally considered to play an important role in the activation of C-H bond [36,37]. Thus the increased number of Lewis acid sites due to the introduction of Cl also makes a contribution to the improved dehydrogenation activity. Besides, XRD and TEM results indicate that the addition of Cl improves the dispersion of CrOx on the catalyst, and significantly decreases the particle size of CrOx, thus restraining the structure-sensitive reactions like coking, and further enhancing the stability of the catalyst. All these above positive effects for CrOx are related to the electron-deficient property of Cl element, which would like to attract electrons from Cr atoms and change the electron state of Cr species, leading to more dispersed CrOx. To further explore the electron modification effect of chlorine on the catalyst, 1-hexene was used as a model compound to investigate the desorption behavior for electron-rich products. There are two types of 1-hexene adsorb on the samples (as shown in Fig. S2b), which the desorption peak centers at ∼ 65 ◦C (peak α) is assigned to the weak adsorption of 1-hexene. The MS signal of 1-hexene drops as the temperature rises to ∼ 280 ◦C due to the strongly adsorbed 1-hexene being consumed with increasing temperature (as shown in Fig. S2c). The strongly adsorbed 1-hexene can not be quantified, thus only discussing the weakly adsorbed 1-hexene on the catalyst, with the profiles shown in Fig. 9. For the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the desorption of 1-hexene starts from 22 oC, peaks at 56 oC, and desorbs completely before 90 oC. The 1-hexene desorption curve shifts to high temperature after adding Cl, and both the starting and peak temperature are increased, indicating that the desorption of 1-hexene for the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst become difficult after introducing Cl, and get harder with Cl loading. Moreover, compared with Cr-K/γ-Al2O3, the amount of desorbed 1-hexene (quantified by six-way valve pulse with gas 1-hexene) is decreased and dropped with Cl content (as listed in Table 2). Cl-modified Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is electron-deficient due to the electronic characteristic of Cl, which exhibits stronger adsorption ability to the electron-rich olefins compared with Cl-free sample. However, the number of inactive Cr-Cl species increases with Cl content, resulting in a decreased number of adsorption sites. Therefore, the desorption temperature for Cl modified catalyst is shifted to higher temperatures, while the amount of adsorbed 1-hexene for Cl modified catalyst is decreased and dropped with Cl content compared with Cr-K/γ-Al2O3. These findings indicate that Cl changed the sorptive nature of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, which is unfavorable for the adsorption of 1-hexene and detrimental to the deep reaction of electron-rich products [38]. However, the promotional effect brings by Cl only works at a lower loading. When excess amount of Cl are present, the inactive metal-Cl species would be formed because of the strong electron-withdrawing property of Cl [39,40], which can be confirmed by XRD, H2-TPR and 1-hexene-TPD results. The characteristic diffraction peaks ascribed to Cr2O3 get weaker and broader as Cl content increases to 1.5 wt% and new diffraction peaks of KCl and CrCl3 are observed for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The difficulty of the reduction of Cr6+ oxides is increased with Cl content, and no reducible CrOx can be detected during the reduction process for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Both the adsorption and desorption of electron-rich hydrocarbons become harder for these Cr-Cl species in Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, which is unfavorable for the reaction [41]. To validate whether the Cr-Cl species lead to the extremely low n-hexane conversion, CrCl3/Al2O3 catalyst was prepared and evaluated for n-hexane dehydrogenation reaction. n-Hexane conversion over CrCl3/x-Al2O3 catalysts with different calcination conditions are shown in Fig. 10. As seen, the more rigorous the calcination condition of CrCl3/x-Al2O3 catalyst is, the lower the n-hexane conversion can be achieved. The n-hexane conversion of CrCl3/γ-Al2O3 catalyst calcinated at 600 oC under air atmosphere for 4 h is 11.0 wt%. Increasing the calcination temperature and lengthening the time decreases the converison further. The CrCl3/θ-Al2O3 catalyst calcinated at 750 oC under N2 atmosphere for 8 h is 0.8 wt%. The change is caused by the structure of CrCl3·6 H2O precursor that the six bound water ([CrCl2(H2O)4]Cl·2 H2O) can not be removed completely by calcining at 600 °C [24]. Calcination under N2 atmosphere and vacuum are beneficial to dehydration without destroying the structure of Cr-Cl. The XRD profiles of CrCl3/x-Al2O3 catalysts with different calcination conditions are given in Fig. S3. All the CrCl3/x-Al2O3 catalysts only exhibit diffraction peaks of Al2O3 rather than that of CrCl3, suggesting that there is no crystalline CrCl3 formed, and further indicative of hard dehydration of CrCl3·6 H2O. The TG-MS results of CrCl3·6 H2O heated in N2 and air atmosphere given in Fig. S4 also confirm it. Therefore, the formation of Cr-Cl species is the reason for the declined n-hexane conversion as the Cl content increases to 1.5 wt% and the extremely low n-hexane conversion for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, the lower specific surface and density of hydroxyl groups of θ-Al2O3 may result in aggregation of Cr species which also lead to the decreased n-hexane conversion of CrCl3/θ-Al2O3 catalyst [42]. On the other hand, introducing Cl to Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 increases the acid amount of the catalyst, including both Lewis and Bronsted acid sites, and the acid number is increased with Cl content. The relationship between the acid content of Cr-K-xCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and the products selectivities are depicted in Fig. S5a. Increasing the acid amount leads to decreased selectivity to dehydrogenation products and increased selectivities to cracking and isomerization products. The impact of acid amount on the products selectivity is not remarkable when it is less than 5 umol/g. Nevertheless, the selectivities to cracking and isomerization products increase steeply while that to dehydrogenation products drop for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3, the acid content of which reaches 6.9 umol/g with the existence of strong acid center. It should also be noted that the Cl content, i.e. the acid number, has little impact on the proportion of the three dehydrogenation products (Fig. 3b). It is depicted in Fig. S5b that both the conversion of n-hexane and the selectivity to benzene decline as the increasing of acid amount, especially for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3. That is, excessive acid centers can not promote the formation of benzene further. In summary, Cl changes the reducibility, the dispersion of CrOx and the proportion of Cr6+ oxides in Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and it affects n-hexane dehydrogenation behaviors based on the Cl contents. A small amount of Cl promotes n-hexane conversion by increasing the proportion of Cr6+ oxides and enhancing the Lewis acidity, inhibits coking reaction and improves the catalytic stability by promoting the dispersion of CrOx and repressing the adsorption of electron-rich products. While excessive Cl would form inactive Cr-Cl species. Meanwhile, Cl also affects the acidity of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, it increases the acid amount of the catalyst, and the acid number increases with Cl content. Increased acid number facilitates isomerization and cracking reactions, especially for the strong acid sites, while it is not conducive to the formation of benzene. 3.2 Effect of Cl on the n-hexane dehydrogenation performance: KCl as precursor Cl promotes n-hexane dehydrogenation performance of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, while the inactive Cr-Cl species would be formed when excess Cl is presented. To avoid the formation of Cr-Cl species, KCl was used as the precursor to replace KNO3 and other Cl sources to further clarify the effect of Cl. Fig. 11 shows the comparison of (a) n-hexane conversion, (b) products selectivity changing with TOS between Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 and Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts with the same potassium content (2.5 wt%). As seen, the initial n-hexane conversion of Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is 61.2 wt%, which is significantly higher than that of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (46.5 wt%). However, the change of n-hexane conversion with TOS over the two catalysts shows a similar trend, indicative of similar relative deactivation rate (1.52 h-1 vs. 1.29 h-1) during the dehydrogenation reaction. The coke content of Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is 2.5 wt% after 4 h reaction, which is lower than that of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (4.7 wt%). While there are little difference in the selectivities to dehydrogenation products and cracking products. For Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, the selectivity to dehydrogenation products is about 93.0 wt%, in which the selectivities to n-hexene, n-hexadiene and benzene are about 20.4 wt%, 2.6 wt% and 70.1 wt%, respectively. The selectivity to isomerization products is less than 1.0 wt% and kept constant during the reaction. The nominal content of Cl in the Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is 2.3 wt% on the premise of the same K content with Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, higher than the previously appropriate Cl content (<1.5 wt%), indicating that the promoting role of Cl in KCl is different from introducing Cl separately (using NH4Cl as a precursor) on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. To validate the role of Cl in KCl on the performance of Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for n-hexane dehydrogenation, several chemical and physical analysis techniques were performed. According to BET results listed in Table S3, little difference can be observed for the textural properties of Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 and Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. Fig. 12a compared H2-TPR behaviors of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 and Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The reduction curves of the two samples almost coincide, and the ratios of Cr6+ oxides to total Cr species for the two catalysts are similar, 9.08 % vs. 8.98 %, suggesting that KCl does not change the proportion of Cr6+ oxides. The XRD patterns of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 and Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are displayed in Fig. 12b. As observed, the diffraction peaks corresponding to Cr2O3 for Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are weaker and broader (see the HWFM information listed in Table S2) compared with Cr-K/γ-Al2O3, suggesting that the crystallinity of Cr2O3 in Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is decreased, and the CrOx species in Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst get more dispersed. Moreover, the TEM image of Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 12c) shows that CrOx appears in small clusters, and no CrOx grains larger than 100 nm can be detected, further confirming that the dispersion of CrOx gets better. Besides, 1-hexene-TPD behaviors of Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 and Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are similar, which are depicted in Fig. 12d. The starting temperature of 1-hexene desorption is the same (22 oC) for the two catalysts. The peak temperature of 1-hexene desorption is 55.5 oC for Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3, slightly lower than that of the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (56 oC). While the amount of 1-hexene desorbed from Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 is a little more than that of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, indicative of weak impact of KCl on the adsorption of olefin products. All of these facts jointly conform that the existing state of Cl introduced in the form of KCl is different from that in the form of NH4Cl. The acid properties of the catalyst were determined by Py-FTIR and NH3-TPD analysis, the Py-FTIR spectra of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 and Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 13a. For Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, higher intensity for the pyridine absorption bands at about 1450, 1490, 1540, 1575, 1595 and 1615 cm-1, especially for the pyridine absorption bands at about 1450, 1490 and 1595 cm-1 can be observed. It suggests that the number of Lewis acid is significantly increases after the introduction of KCl, and the impact of Cl in KCl on Lewis acid sites is greater than that on Bronsted acid sites. The NH3-TPD profiles of Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst are exhibited in Fig. 13b. Three inseparable NH3 desorption peaks at 120–550 oC assigned to the weak acid center (I), medium strong acid center (II) and strong acid center (III) [30] can be observed. KCl brings strong acid centers (III) to Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, and the desorption temperature of NH3 rises compared with that of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (150–350 oC). The total number of acid sites for Cr-KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst is 5.49 umol/g, more than twice the total acid number on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (3.27 umol/g). The improved Lewis acidity would contribute to the increased conversion of n-hexane. The TG results of KCl heated in air atmosphere are depicted in Fig. S6. The mass loss at about 350 oC is caused by dehydration, and the mass loss starts at about 750 oC is due to the melting and evaporation of KCl. It suggests that KCl is stable during the experiment, consistent with the study of Decker [25]. That is probably the reason for the unchanged selectivities to cracking and isomerization products. Consequently, KCl not only neutralizes excess acid sites by replacing H+ of OH- group on the Al2O3, but also improves the dispersion of CrOx, and modifies the acidity of Cr/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The improved dispersion of CrOx leads to the decreased coke deposition, and the increased Lewis acidity improves n-hexane conversion. Moreover, probably due to the connection between K and Cl, there is no Cr-Cl species formed, which can be confirmed by 1-hexene-TPD results. However, the conversion of n-hexane does not increase continuously with the KCl loading, as seen in Fig. S7. This is mainly caused by the increased effective activation energy in alkane dehydrogenation due to the presence of excess K [43]. Besides, the BET surface area and pore volume decrease with KCl loading due to the blockage of the channel, as listed in Table S4. 4 Conclusion The introduction of appropriate amount of Cl (NH4Cl as a precursor) to Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst obviously improves n-hexane dehydrogenation performance. According to the characterization results, the added Cl increases the number of dehydrogenation active sites (Cr6+ oxides), facilitates the dispersion of CrOx, and represses the adsorption of electron-rich products (1-hexene). As a result, the n-hexane conversion is improved, side reactions like coking are inhibited, and the stability is enhanced. The optimal reaction results are obtained on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with 1.0 wt% Cl loading. The conversion of n-hexane can reach 52.2 wt%, the selectivity to dehydrogenation products is 87.7 wt% and the coke content after 4 h reaction is decreased to 2.0 wt%. However, introducing Cl increases the number of acid sites of the sample, and strong acid sites appeared for Cr-K-10Cl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, consequently, the formation of isomerization and cracking products are facilitated, and the selectivity to dehydrogenation products including benzene is decreased. Moreover, due to the strong electron-withdrawing property, excessive Cl leads to the formation of unreducible Cr-Cl species, and the adsorption and desorption of hydrocarbons become harder, leading to an extremely low activity. While introducing Cl in the form of KCl can avoid these negative effects. Different from NH4Cl, KCl increases the number of Lewis acid sites, and inhibits the formation of Cr-Cl species due to the strong link between Cl and K. Therefore, n-hexane conversion is significantly increased to 61.2 wt%, and the selectivity to dehydrogenation products rises to 93.1 wt% due to the promoted desorption of electron-rich products (1-hexene). coredata.dc:description: Dehydrogenation of n-hexane on Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can produce n-hexenes and benzene efficiently, while the catalyst deactivates rapidly. This work discovers that introducing an appropriate amount of Cl (NH4Cl) to the Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst can significantly improve catalytic activity and enhance stability, which is caused by increased proportion of Cr6+ oxides and number of Lewis acid sites, improved dispersion of CrOx and depressed coke deposition. While excessive Cl further increases the acidity of the catalyst, accelerating the side reactions like cracking and isomerization, meanwhile the inactive Cr-Cl species are formed inevitably. Surprisingly, introducing Cl in the form of KCl can effectively avoid these negative influences owing to the strong interaction between Cl and K. For 13 wt%Cr-2.5 wt%KCl/γ-Al2O3 catalyst, 61.2 wt% of n-hexane conversion, 93.1 wt% of selectivity to dehydrogenation products can be achieved, in which the selectivities to n-hexene and benzene are 20.4 wt% and 70.1 wt%, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of chlorine on the performance of Cr-K/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for n-hexane dehydrogenation
